seg.output: Alas, most learned Buller, I lament that I have been driven from my home and am in exile among the Tigurines. From this situation I estimate that your affection for me is such that I may correspondingly love more ardently one whom I had previously held in unknown esteem. And with no less affection do we read all of your laments concerning our faithlessness, in which we have betrayed our pledges, God, and our allies. We have indeed betrayed them—though it was not our fault, although it was also ours for not doing our utmost to oppose the crime. Moreover, when the treaty was first proposed by our and foreign rulers and magnates, an oath of secrecy was taken and the sealing of documents, and the entire army was never adequately informed of the terms of the peace. For when they returned, they reported that peace had been made, but few or none could reveal what kind of peace it was. The reason for this was that our leaders and magnates, those who had conducted the negotiations, were all either Evangelical haters or pretenders, with only two or three exceptions. Thus, they clandestinely and wickedly conducted everything. Moreover, all authority was taken away from those whose piety was genuine and who understood the cunning of these men, this as a result of the recent defeat at the Battle of Cappel.

seg.output: We read with no less affection all those who preside over Zurich, your lament of our treachery, in which we breached our faith and our treaties, God and our allies. And indeed we did, though it was another's fault, though it is also ours for not opposing such a great crime. In the beginning of the treaty, the heads of the emperors and magnates, both foreign and domestic, were so outlined that immediately an oath of silence intervened and the sealing of seals and the whole army was never solidly taught what the heads of peace were. For on their return they said that peace had been made, but what kind of peace had been made, no one or very few disclosed. The cause was that our leaders and magnates who were dealing with peace were all, except two or three, either enemies or pretenders of the evangelical affair. So they secretly and wickedly set up everything. But the others, to whom the craftiness of these was inherited and who cared for piety, all authority was taken away, and that because of the recent defeat suffered at Cappellas. For they were always hearing, if anything more reasonable was suggested, whether enough of the citizens' and Christian blood had not been shed yet, the battle being sought against the will of Mars and Minerva, the victors being conquered without great harm, meanwhile the land being ruined, buildings being devastated and both private and public wealth being exhausted, and that after the greatest hunger suffered for three years a greater pestilence would follow, and that the mountaineers could not be conquered and men extinguished, but that we could be consumed by a long war, not by our enemies, but by our own misfortune. The people stood there amazed, having been beaten and chased for the second time, in general dumbfounded, deprived of experienced, pious and just leaders, tired of warlike matters, and finally eager for any kind of peace.

seg.output: We read with no less love all of those who preside over Zurich, your lamentation of our breach of faith in which we betrayed our God, our allies, and our treaties. Indeed, we did betray them, though it was not entirely our fault, although we too bear some of the blame for not opposing such a heinous crime. At the beginning of the agreement, the terms were outlined by our and foreign emperors and nobles, and soon an oath of secrecy and the sealing of documents was made and the entire army was never properly informed of the peace terms. When they returned, they said that peace had been made, but no one or very few could explain what kind of peace had been made. The reason being that our leaders and nobles who were negotiating the peace, with the exception of two or three, were either enemies of or feigned to be in favor of the gospel. Thus, everything was arranged in a clandestine and unholy manner. As for the others, for whom the craftiness of these men was a model and who had an interest in piety, all authority was taken away from them, due to the recent defeat at Cappel. For always, if something more reasonable was proposed, they were asked whether enough of our citizens and Christian blood had not yet been shed, that war should be joined against the will of Mars and Minerva, that the victors should not be conquered without great harm, that in the meantime the fields should perish, buildings be destroyed, and private and public wealth be exhausted, and that after the great famine which we have suffered for three years, a greater plague should follow, and that the mountains could not be subdued and the people extinguished, but we ourselves should be consumed by a long war, not of the enemy, but of our own misfortune. The people stood aghast, already struck down and driven away a second time, in general stunned, deprived of experienced, pious, and just leaders, weary of military affairs, and finally, eager for any kind of peace. Taking advantage of these opportunities, the old men did without any difficulty what they had planned. From this emerged the glorious peace with which we betrayed both God and men.

seg.output: We read with no less affection all who preside over Tyguri, your lamentation of our perfidy, in which we betrayed faith and treaties, God and our allies. And indeed we betrayed, but through the fault of others, although there is also our own, since we did not oppose such a great crime. Moreover, the articles of the treaty were outlined by the emperors and magnates, both our own and foreign, in such a way that a sworn silence was imposed and the whole army was never fully taught what the terms of peace were. For when they returned they said that peace had been made, but what kind of peace had been made, no one or very few revealed. The reason was that our leaders and magnates, who were negotiating the peace, were all, with two or three exceptions, either opponents or feigned opponents of the evangelical cause. Secretly and impiously, therefore, they arranged everything. All authority was taken away from the others, whose guile was begotten by these men and who cherished piety, and this was due to the recent defeat at Cappellas. For they were constantly hearing, if something more prudent was proposed, whether enough citizens and Christian blood had not already been shed; that, contrary to the will of Mars and Minerva, battle should be sought; that the victors should not be overcome without great loss; meanwhile, that field and buildings should be destroyed and private and public wealth exhausted; and that, after the great famine which we have endured for the last three years, a greater pestilence will follow; and that the mountaineers cannot be defeated and the men extinguished, while we can be consumed by a long war, not by the enemy, but by our own misfortune. The people stood amazed, twice already beaten and driven away, in general stupefied, destitute of skilful, pious, and just leaders, wearied of war, and finally eager for any kind of peace. Taking advantage of these occasions, the veterans accomplished what they had planned without any difficulty. Henceforth that excellent peace, by which we betrayed both God and men, emerged for us. Now for the first time, the greater part of the people begin to feel and grieve over it. Nevertheless, there is something to confess and detest the crime committed.

seg.output: We read with no less love for all of those who preside over Tyguri of this lament of yours for our treachery, by which we betrayed faith and treaties, God and allies. And truly we did betray, but it was due to another's fault, although it is also ours, that we did not oppose our heads to such a great crime. Furthermore, in the beginning of the agreement, the terms proposed by our and foreign emperors and magnates were so obscure, that, immediately, an oath of silence was made and sealed with seals, and the whole army was never well informed of what the terms of peace were. For, when they returned, they said that peace had been made, but what kind of peace it was, no one, or very few, revealed. The cause was, that our leaders and magnates, who negotiated the peace, all, except two or three, either despised the divine business or were mere pretenders. Thus, in a clandestine and wicked way, they did everything. But to the others, to whom the craft of these was a heritage, and to whom piety was dear, all authority was taken away, and this due to the recent defeat at Cappellas. For they heard perpetually, if any more prudent thing was proposed, whether enough of the citizens' and Christians' blood had not yet been shed, to provoke the war, against the will of Mars and Minerva, that the victors would not be conquered without great loss, meanwhile, that the fields would perish, buildings be laid waste, and private and public wealth be exhausted, and that, after the great famine endured for three years, a greater one was to follow, nor that the mountaineers could be vanquished and extinguished, but that we could be destroyed by a long war, not by the enemy, but by our own misfortune. The people stood astonished, already twice beaten and fled, in general, stupid, destitute of expert, pious and just leaders, tired of military affairs, and, finally, avid of any kind of peace. But, taking advantage of these occasions, the veterans did, without any difficulty, what they had prepared. Thus, from here, issued to us that excellent peace, by which we betrayed both God and men. Which now, for the first time, the greater part of the people begins to perceive and regret. Yet, something has been done, to confess and detest the crime. You will pray to the Lord, that he may have mercy on us. Now, indeed, he has humbled us, so that, whereas we were until now a mirror in the strength and constancy of the churches, so now we may be an example and a wonder to all nations.

and public resources exhausted, and that after the greatest hunger we had suffered for three years, a greater plague would follow, and that the mountaineers could not be subdued and people Moreover, what you write that the Zurich apology is flying through all Germany with letters and instruments, rather impudently pretending necessity and the people's will, we marvel at.Believe that it is not made by the Zurichers, but forged and spread by others.For we know for certain that the Zurichers have not published anything else except for an apology to you, which they share with all Germany.But this we do not know nor do we believe."But we foresaw this disaster, these betrayals and civil disputes," you say, "and therefore we wanted to make peace through our own."

seg.output: We are amazed that you write that the Zurich excuse is travelling throughout Germany by letter and document, quite impudently as if it were hiding necessity and the will of the people. Believe it to be a fiction and an exaggeration made by someone other than the Zurich. We are certain that the Zurich have not issued any of these things, except offering an apology to you, which all of Germany will share. However, we do not know and do not believe it. “But we had foreseen this disaster, these betrayals and civil disputes,” you say. “Therefore, we wanted to make peace through our people. Why did you not heed our holy warnings?” We would have heard if we had ever hoped that wild men could be softened by patience, since even now, after experiencing so much damage and our blood and patience, they have not been softened, but had already decided to use force and arms to take control when our people were seeking peace. What more can I say? You will see the just causes soon enough, you will see our patience when we send Zwingli’s life to Ziegler. For in this matter, nothing was wrong on our part.

seg.output: We are amazed that you write that the Zurich apology has circulated throughout Germany by letter and instrument, impudently enough, in that it pretends necessity and the will of the people. Believe that it was fabricated and spread by others than the Zurich people. We know for sure that the Zurich people have not published anything about these matters, unless they have sent an apology to your people, which all of Germany will share. Yet we neither know nor believe this. "But we foresaw this disaster and civil dissensions," you say, "and so we wanted to make peace through our people. Why did you not listen to the sacred admonitions?" We would indeed have listened, if we ever could have hoped that fierce men could be softened by patience, since even now, after so much damage sustained, they are not softened, and already at the time when our people were seeking peace, they had already determined to undertake the matter by force and arms. Why say more? You will one day see the just causes, you will see the long-suffering patience of our people, when we send Zwingli's life to Ziegler. In this matter we have not sinned on our part. The evil arose from the Lord, to test us, not that we should be utterly destroyed. Moreover, the Lord's will is holy and just. We are therefore not only amazed, but even struck dumb, dear brothers, when you write that you do not know what appears to be the most reasonable course according to the doctrine of the Church among us, which has not turned out well for us.

seg.output: We are amazed at what you write, that the people of Zurich would have the audacity to spread their defense throughout all of Germany by letter and instrument, as if they were trying to disguise their desperation as the will of the people. Believe it or not, it was not the Zurich people who invented and propagated this. We know for certain that they have not issued anything on these matters, except to send an apology to you, and that it would be shared with all of Germany. However, this is something we neither know nor believe. “But did we not foresee this disaster, these betrayals and civil discord?” you ask. “That is why we sought to make peace through our own people. Why then did you not hear our warnings?” We would have heard them, had we ever been able to hope that wicked men could be softened by patience, for they are still not softened by our blood and patience, despite all the wrongs they have done us. Even then, when we sought peace, they had determined to take matters by force and arms. What’s the use of saying more? You will one day see the just causes and the patience of our people when we send Zwingli’s life to Ziegler. For in this matter, nothing is to be blamed on us. The Lord has allowed evil to come forth, so that we may be tried, not utterly destroyed. But the Lord’s will is holy and just. Therefore, when you write that you do not know what civil and human response has been seen in our doctrine, which has not been good to us, we not only marvel, beloved brothers, but also stand amazed. For if we should judge any matter by the event and misfortune, who will not regret the teaching of the Christian prophets, which after so much work does not rudely give, but takes away life, and has deprived us of the best men in the Lord, Isaiah, Zachariah, Stephen, James, and countless other heroes, to whom the true religion has been most unkind? If our doctrine responds to civil and human matters because we have encouraged the Christian magistrates to free the oppressed, maintain equity, practice justice, punish crimes and criminals, I ask, what did the divine prophets preach?

seg.output: We are also amazed at what you write that the excuse of the people of Zurich, in the form of letters and documents, has been widely circulated throughout Germany, claiming necessity and the will of the people. Believe rather that this is a fabrication and something spread about by those other than the people of Zurich. We are certain that the people of Zurich have not issued anything else except an apology to you, which all Germany will share. However, we neither know nor believe this. "But we had foreseen this disaster and these civil quarrels," you say, "so we wanted to negotiate peace through our own. Why then did you not hear the holy warnings?" Indeed, we would have heard, if we could ever have hoped that wild men could be moderated by leniency, since even now, after all the damage, they are not softened by our blood nor by our long-suffering, indeed, even then, when our people sought peace, they had completely resolved to attack by force and arms. What more is there to say? You will eventually see just causes, you will see the long-suffering patience of our own, when we will send the life of our Zwingli to Ziegler. For in this matter, nothing wrong has been done by us. Evil has come forth from the Lord, to test us, not to utterly destroy us. But the Lord's will is holy and just. Therefore, when you write that you do not know what civil and humane course of action has been seen to benefit the doctrine of the Church among us, which has not gone well for us, we not only marvel, dear brothers, but we are astounded. For if we are to judge any matter by its outcome and misfortune, then who will not regret the Christian prophecy, which, after many efforts, does not give generously, but has deprived us of life and taken away the best men in the Lord, Isaiah, Zachariah, Stephen, Jacob, and countless other heroes, to whom true religion has gone very badly? But if our doctrine is seen as civil and humane because we have encouraged the Christian magistrate to free the oppressed, to preserve justice, to cultivate righteousness, to punish crimes and criminals, then what, I ask, have the divine prophets preached? Nor do we give an answer that their function was different from ours, when common sense does not allow it.

seg.output: We marvel at what you write, that the Tigurini are flying about Germany with letters and documents claiming self-defense and the people's will as their excuse. Believe it only if it comes from anyone but the Tigurini, for we know for certain that they have produced nothing but an apology to you, which all of Germany will share. We do not know or believe this. "But," you ask, "did we not foresee this disaster, these betrayals and civil discord? That is why we wanted peace negotiated by our people. Why then did you not heed our warnings?" We would have, had we been able to hope that these savage people could be softened by our patience, for they are not softened by our blood and patience even now, after so much suffering, and had already resolved to pursue the matter by force and arms when we were seeking peace. What more is there to say? You will soon see the justice of our cause and our patience, when we send Zuingli's life to Ziegler. In this matter we have done nothing wrong. The Lord has sent out this evil to test us, not to destroy us. But the Lord's will is holy and just. So when you write that you do not know what humane and civil course of action is consistent with our doctrine, which has not been good to us, we not only marvel, dearest brothers, but we are astounded. For if we are to judge by the event and misfortune, who would not regret the Christian prophecy, which, after so much labor, does not grant a rude reward, but has taken the life of the best men in the Lord, Isaiah, Zachariah, Stephen, Jacob, and countless other heroes, all of whom have met with very poor fortune in true religion? If then our doctrine is seen as humane and civil because we have encouraged the Christian magistrate to free the oppressed, preserve justice, and punish crimes and criminals, what did the prophets of God preach? For they do not condemn, etc. Shall we then say that their function was different from ours, when common sense does not permit it? For no one is ignorant that the things which pertain to justice and judgment have never been abolished, nor has the magistrate in the Church of Christ been abolished.
